message.content: Since we want $\sqrt{a}-b$ to be positive, it must be the positive root of the given equation of a quadratic. By moving the $73$ to the left side of the equation, we have $x^2+12x-73 = 0$. We want to make this equation into the form $(x - \sqrt{a}+b)(x - \sqrt{a}-b) = 0$. Since the coefficient of $x^2$ is $1$, we know that $x=\sqrt{a}+b -(\sqrt{a}-b)=2b$. Since $2b = -12 \Longrightarrow b = -6$, we can substitute to get $-12 = \sqrt{a} + -6 \Longrightarrow \sqrt{a} = -6 - -12 = 6$, so $a = 36$. Thus $a+b=36+6=\boxed{42}$.
